I did not trace the course of this line to the West coast,
but proceeding Eastward, I observed it <s>again<\s> between
Loch Chon and Loch Ard striking N65E, & again a
few hundred yards above the foot of Loch Ketterin striking N45E in both cases through Slate.
There <s>have<\s> are obviously <s>been<\s> some faults in this district
which have broken the line and thrown its eastern end
to the Southward. In Strath Earn the boundary
of the slate trends somewhat Southward of it's previous
course ; but this has not altered the direction of the
of the perpendicular plane, which runs N60E through the
Mica Schist 1½ mile south of St. Fillan’s: <s>thus thus
formation of the Mica Schist thus continues vertical
along nearly the same plane as the cleavage of the Slates<\s>
The line <s>appears to<\s> follows <s>exactly<\s> nearly the same direction
through Perthshire without further disturbance,
running N45E through the Clay Slate on the north
side of Dunkeld; through Mica Schist at the
Brig-o-Cally with a strike of N50E beyond
which spot I did not follow it. Thus along the
Highland border the <s>vertical<\s> foliation of the Mica
Schist & the cleavage of the Slate are both vertical
along lines so closely corresponding, that they may
are laid down on the geological maps of Sutherland and Banffshire by the late Mr:
Cunningham published in the 46th & 57th numbers of the Journal
of the Highland Society for September 1839 & June 1842: these have been of great service to me.
